Ghost Recon Breakpoint is one of those games that can be fun when you are in the right mood for it, but it is definitely not perfect. It is a tactical open world shooter set on Auroa, a huge island filled with drones, enemy bases, mountains, forests, and little towns. The map is big and looks good, and there is a lot of space to explore, but the gameplay can feel uneven depending on what you like.

The story centers around Nomad surviving a helicopter crash and trying to stop a group of former Ghosts who went rogue. The setup is interesting, and the world itself has a nice mix of natural areas and tech heavy zones, but the missions can feel repetitive after a while. You end up clearing a lot of enemy camps, gathering intel, and doing similar objectives across the map.

The shooting and stealth mechanics work well once you get used to them. Breakpoint is at its best when you slow down, plan your approach, and take out enemies quietly. Playing solo with AI teammates is better now than it was at launch, but the game still feels like it was designed with co-op in mind. It is more enjoyable with a friend.

The gear system is one of the things people either love or ignore. You collect weapons and armor with different scores, similar to a looter shooter. Some players enjoy upgrading everything, and some prefer the more realistic Ghost Recon style without gear levels. Thankfully, later updates added more options to tailor how you play.

Exploration is a big part of the game. Auroa has mountains, swamps, snowy regions, and hidden bunkers. The world design is one of the stronger parts of Breakpoint, and it is easy to lose time just traveling around and gathering supplies. The vehicles are hit or miss, but the helicopter makes life easier.

Breakpoint had a rough launch, but Ubisoft patched a lot of issues, added the immersive mode, improved AI teammates, and gave players more control over difficulty and realism. The game is much better now than when it first came out.

Overall, Ghost Recon Breakpoint can be enjoyable if you like tactical shooters, open worlds, and slow paced stealth gameplay. It is not as polished as some other titles, but it has a huge map, solid gunplay, and plenty to do if you enjoy exploring and clearing missions at your own pace.

Ghost Recon Breakpoint é um jogo que tenta ser muitas coisas ao mesmo tempo e acaba se perdendo em várias delas. Ele tem seus pontos positivos, como o visual incrível da ilha de Auroa, que é realmente impressionante e cheia de detalhes. A ambientação é linda, variada e convida à exploração, com florestas densas, montanhas, bases futuristas e paisagens que parecem saídas de um filme. A jogabilidade em equipe também pode ser divertida, especialmente se você tiver amigos para jogar junto. Quando o grupo trabalha em sincronia, o jogo consegue entregar momentos de ação tática bem empolgantes, dignos da franquia Ghost Recon. O sistema de sobrevivência, embora não seja perfeito, adiciona um toque interessante: ferimentos, fadiga e a necessidade de cuidar do equipamento dão uma sensação mais realista e tensa às missões.

Mas é impossível ignorar o que o jogo tem de errado. Breakpoint foi lançado cheio de problemas técnicos, bugs e decisões de design questionáveis. O sistema de progressão baseado em níveis e equipamentos fez o jogo parecer mais um looter shooter genérico do que um título tático da série. Isso quebrou boa parte da imersão e afastou muitos fãs antigos que esperavam algo mais autêntico. Além disso, a inteligência artificial dos inimigos e dos companheiros (no início do jogo) era incrivelmente inconsistente, às vezes te ignorando completamente ou te detectando de forma absurda. Mesmo após várias atualizações, o jogo ainda carrega uma sensação de desequilíbrio em várias partes.

E o ponto mais polêmico de todos: as microtransações. No lançamento, Breakpoint praticamente implorava para o jogador gastar dinheiro real em quase tudo — armas, veículos, cosméticos e até melhorias que afetavam a jogabilidade. Isso deu a impressão de um jogo pensado mais para vender do que para entreter. Embora a Ubisoft tenha ajustado um pouco isso com o tempo, a mancha ficou. A sensação de que o jogo foi construído em torno de uma loja de microtransações e não da diversão é algo difícil de ignorar.

No fim das contas, Ghost Recon Breakpoint tem bons momentos, principalmente quando jogado com amigos e quando você se esforça para aproveitar o que ele faz de certo: a ambientação, a cooperação e a sensação de estar em uma operação militar. Mas é um jogo que exige paciência, tolerância aos defeitos e uma boa dose de boa vontade. Para quem é fã da franquia e quer ver o lado positivo, ele ainda pode oferecer horas de diversão. Para quem espera um jogo polido e coerente com o legado tático de Ghost Recon, Breakpoint infelizmente é uma grande decepção.

[h3] Ubisoft Devs Makes Fun Games [/h3] 
  Ubisoft has this knack of developing good games with solid core gameplay mechanics, while making extremely poor executive decisions at the same time. When you purchase Breakpoint and hop in to play single player, you're signing up for the opportunity to tackle an entire nations worth of main and side missions as loudly or as quietly as you'd like. You'll literally never be at a loss for things to do since there's always a new weapon or gadget to collect, a hidden cache to unearth, or a roaming patrol to practice your CQC on for unlocks & steam achievements.

  The story is engaging enough; we control a Ghost who leads a team of Ghosts against our ex-best-friend Ghost who's basically a Nazi now. In the free story arc, we work towards dismantling the military junta that took over the island. Engaging in the other two stories (guerilla faction warfare, stop the chemical terrorist plot) requires paying anywhere between 25$-7.99$ depending on Steam Sale status. I got nearly 50-60 hours just on the first story arc alone. First on PS4, then again in coop mode on PC.

  From a gamer who appreciates stealth action gameplay, I was elated to find that the stealth mechanics for this game are cromulent. Battlefield 6 gives you the option to bellycrawl up to an enemy for a surprise knife kill, but outside of claymore placement there isn't much you can do to play around a subterfuge mechanic. Metal Gear Solid V gives you an entire arsenal dedicated to eliminating enemy threats with everything EXCEPT a bullet fired from a gun. Here, Breakpoint strikes a healthy balance between the two wherein we have a couple throwable items to distract foot soldiers, some cool gadgets to kill troops in unique and thoughtful ways, multiple different skill/class trees, upgradeable and customizable weapons for all range styles, and an impressive NPC team who can take aim at specific targets and only fire when we're ready to coordinate as much as a septuple kill all without being spotted. I've gone from 800km sniping to up blitzkrieg shotgunner in the course of 20 minutes before and it's nice to know the option is there should I want a breath of fresh air in gameplay style.

Solo or with one-to-three of your friends, this is a great game to drop 60+ hours on. 

[h3] Ubisoft Execs Ruin Fun Games [/h3]
  Unfortunately, Ubisoft isn't deserving of your money. The dev team who created this experience should be lauded for their efforts. The executives that continue to ignore prevailing popular sentiment on things like DRM & Always-On requirements, exploitative monetization practices, crunch time, and more deserve to be fired from a cannon into the sun, along with every single private equity entity that has ever or will ever come to exist. The Stock Market is actively ruining the videogames you like, often on purpose. As consumers, whether we have purchased this game or not, we owe it to ourselves to make our voices heard in the hopes that someone in the rank-&-file hears us and tries to make a change or the better.

[h3] Buy It On Sale [/h3]
  You can get the whole kit 'n kaboodle on sale twice a year for a total of maybe 20 bucks... that's Deluxe Edition plus the Year 1 pass. That will get you the extra classes that they locked behind a paywall, as well as the other 2/3rds of the story that they also locked behind a paywall. Then you can enjoy the game and all it has to offer for 7 years, at which point Ubisoft will probably be on their "nobody owns anything at all arc" and they'll find a way to claw back your Steam key & remove your access to the games you rented on this platform.

Ghost Recon Breakpoint isn't terrible, it's a solid open-world tactical shooter that delivers familiar sneaking, shooting, and co-op against rogue Wolves on a sprawling island, with decent visuals and gear customization. However, it barely improves on Wildlands, feeling like a sidegrade with unchanged mechanics; the Auroa map comes off empty and rushed, its biomes blending blandly without the predecessor's lived-in detail, leading to monotonous exploration. The story, involving betrayal and a Jon Bernthal villain, lacks compelling tension amid fetch quests and predictable intrigue. Fine for fans of the series, but skippable otherwise.

My Take:
I didn’t play for long because I honestly couldn’t stomach the game it was really bad. The graphics were so poor that I could easily pull up a game from 2015 that looks way better than this. I really want to give Ubisoft a good review, but come on… their recent projects have been disappointing. It’s no surprise their stock has dropped; the company feels like it’s going downhill with the quality of their games. Even their latest release is garbage don’t waste your time.

Where to begin with this?
The user Interface is very unintuitive, and it takes far too long to find a quest to do.
The gameplay is meh, it's really nothing special, and it's brought down by a few annoying design choices. The game is littered with your standard Ubisoft collect-a-thon gameplay, much of which are cosmetic items so you can play dress-up.

The contextual button controls mean you can't always do what you want to do because something else is also in the area and takes priority. For example: Picking up someone else's gun may take priority over grabbing a guy who might turn around at any moment as both use the same button, this can very easily result in death.

It's also weirdly difficult to make Nomad do what you want him to do. Crouching behind cover and want to peek? too bad, because Nomad wants to face the other way and will walk backwards to avoid turning around. Want to parachute off of this overlook? Not today Nomad, you're going to tumble down a cliff. Want to stand on this slightly smaller box so you can climb on something else? Nope, vault over it only.

But the worst crime of this game? They clearly planned out a lengthy story and designed the game for this, they then locked 2/3 of it (including main story missions) behind an additional DLC paywall. At full price, that's a $100 game.

"Episode 1 is an entire game!"
No, it's not, there's virtually no resolution. There's still plenty of big-bads we haven't met, we're still stuck on the island thanks to the drone perimeter, even the pretense that sent us to the island in the first place has barely been fulfilled. The 'boss' of episode 1 (the base game) is just a tiny cog in the machine so there is absolutely zero sense of completion when you kill him. Heck, due to the janky way the objectives work, I killed him, engaged in 3 more main story missions that behaved like I hadn't, and then went back to [spoiler]blow up the sub[/spoiler] so he wasn't even a final boss.

And no, this game does not seem to have been advertised as episodic, so comparing it to most episodic games is not a good equivalency.

The scenery is pretty nice, if you can get past the far too frequent floating rock or tree, and the all-too-frequent occurrence of getting stuck inside of a rock you pressed a button to climb on top of.

Awful game, they took the bones of Wildlands and added a bunch of crap over the top while half-assing the story experience of the game. Go play Wildlands instead for a much more cohesive and well rounded experience, this game feels like it doesn't know what it wants to be.

[h3] Ubisoft Devs Makes Fun Games [/h3] 
  Ubisoft has this knack of developing good games with solid core gameplay mechanics, while making extremely poor executive decisions at the same time. When you purchase Breakpoint and hop in to play single player, you're signing up for the opportunity to tackle an entire nations worth of main and side missions as loudly or as quietly as you'd like. You'll literally never be at a loss for things to do since there's always a new weapon or gadget to collect, a hidden cache to unearth, or a roaming patrol to practice your CQC on for unlocks & steam achievements.

  The story is engaging enough; we control a Ghost who leads a team of Ghosts against our ex-best-friend Ghost who's basically a Nazi now. In the free story arc, we work towards dismantling the military junta that took over the island. Engaging in the other two stories (guerilla faction warfare, stop the chemical terrorist plot) requires paying anywhere between 25$-7.99$ depending on Steam Sale status. I got nearly 50-60 hours just on the first story arc alone. First on PS4, then again in coop mode on PC.

  From a gamer who appreciates stealth action gameplay, I was elated to find that the stealth mechanics for this game are cromulent. Battlefield 6 gives you the option to bellycrawl up to an enemy for a surprise knife kill, but outside of claymore placement there isn't much you can do to play around a subterfuge mechanic. Metal Gear Solid V gives you an entire arsenal dedicated to eliminating enemy threats with everything EXCEPT a bullet fired from a gun. Here, Breakpoint strikes a healthy balance between the two wherein we have a couple throwable items to distract foot soldiers, some cool gadgets to kill troops in unique and thoughtful ways, multiple different skill/class trees, upgradeable and customizable weapons for all range styles, and an impressive NPC team who can take aim at specific targets and only fire when we're ready to coordinate as much as a septuple kill all without being spotted. I've gone from 800km sniping to up blitzkrieg shotgunner in the course of 20 minutes before and it's nice to know the option is there should I want a breath of fresh air in gameplay style.

Solo or with one-to-three of your friends, this is a great game to drop 60+ hours on. 

[h3] Ubisoft Execs Ruin Fun Games [/h3]
  Unfortunately, Ubisoft isn't deserving of your money. The dev team who created this experience should be lauded for their efforts. The executives that continue to ignore prevailing popular sentiment on things like DRM & Always-On requirements, exploitative monetization practices, crunch time, and more deserve to be fired from a cannon into the sun, along with every single private equity entity that has ever or will ever come to exist. The Stock Market is actively ruining the videogames you like, often on purpose. As consumers, whether we have purchased this game or not, we owe it to ourselves to make our voices heard in the hopes that someone in the rank-&-file hears us and tries to make a change or the better.

[h3] Buy It On Sale [/h3]
  You can get the whole kit 'n kaboodle on sale twice a year for a total of maybe 20 bucks... that's Deluxe Edition plus the Year 1 pass. That will get you the extra classes that they locked behind a paywall, as well as the other 2/3rds of the story that they also locked behind a paywall. Then you can enjoy the game and all it has to offer for 7 years, at which point Ubisoft will probably be on their "nobody owns anything at all arc" and they'll find a way to claw back your Steam key & remove your access to the games you rented on this platform.
